titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of his papers at Syracuse University

list.item: 13 Jul 2021 - scrapbooks rehoused, American Mercury correspondence added (MRC)

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Correspondence, manuscripts of the American military, naval, and science fiction novelist.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Fletcher Pratt (1897-1956) was an American military, naval, and science fiction novelist. Born in Buffalo, New York, Pratt is said to have been raised on an Indian reservation. He attended Hobart College for a year. During World War I he served with the War Library Service. During his intensive writing career, Pratt wrote chiefly on military and naval subjects, but also in the field of science fiction, collaborating often with L. Sprague DeCamp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p:
The Fletcher Pratt Papers consists of correspondence-subject files, manuscripts and research material, and a small amount of printed material and memorabila.
Correspondence is primarily with publications (
Atlanta Journal,
Fantasy and Science Fiction,
Harper's Magazine,
The Infantry Journal,
Pacific Spectator) and publishers (Ballantine Books, Bobbs-Merrill, Doubleday & Company, Gnome Press, Henry Holt and Company, Penguin) but also includes a few organizations (e.g., Science Fiction League of America).
Subject files cover miscellaneous topics, most relating to either the Navy (British Navy at War, First Philippine Sea, 4th Fleet, German Navy) or general military (Eleven Generals, Macarthur, Munitions and equipment, Pearl Harbor, Spies/espionage).
Manuscripts and research material contains material for more than 150 articles, essays, stories, and other pieces of writing by Pratt, as well as a small amount of printed material (book reviews, published stories and similar).
Memorabilia contains clippings and nine scrapbooks.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The majority of our archival and manuscript collections are housed offsite and require advanced notice for retrieval. Researchers are encouraged to contact us in advance concerning the collection material they wish to access for their research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Written permission must be obtained from SCRC and all relevant rights holders before publishing quotations, excerpts or images from any materials in this collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

note.p: Pages of all scrapbooks are EXTREMELY brittle. Handle as little, and as carefully, as possible.
